title: Notes on Loss Functions
text:
Loss Function or Cost Function or Error Function

Background


Why Loss function
The purpose of loss function is to quantify the error between the output of an algorithm and the given target value.

Let‚Äôs say that I have 100 pieces of something and I want the algorithm to predict the number of pieces available. Here, 100 pieces are the ground truth or the target value. Now, if the algorithm predicts that there are only 90 pieces, there is a loss or error of 10 pieces.



Types of Loss Functions

NCE
InfoNCE
NT-Xent
Contrastive Loss
Triplet Loss

InfoNCE (Information Noise Contrastive Estimation) loss uses positive examples and sampled negative examples to contrast a true data distribution with a noise distribution. InfoNCE uses categorical cross-entropy loss to identify the positive sample amongst a set of unrelated noise samples. InfoNCE is an extension of NCE loss that adds a concept of mutual information to the loss calculation. Mutual information measures the amount of information shared between two random variables. InfoNCE loss aims to maximize the mutual information between the representations of the true target and its context while minimizing the mutual info between the representations of the true target and the noise samples.
NT-XENT (Normalized Temperature scaled Cross entropy) loss is a variant of InfoNCE loss that introduces a temperature parameter to control the smoothness of the similarity distribution, which can help with training stability and convergence. The higher temperature (Tau) encourages a softer distribution, making it easier for the model to distinguish between positive and negative sample.


Thoughts:

title: Notes on Activation Functions
text:
Activation functions are very widely used in neural networks. Activation function is a function that calculates the output of the node. Why is it named activation function? It decides whether the neuron should be activated or not. It calculates the weighted sum and further adds bias to the neuron. They are also known as Transfer Function. Why? It transforms the summed weighted input from the node into an output value to be transferred to the next hidden layer or as output.

Background





Why activation function
The purpose of activation function is to add non-linearity to the neural network.


Types of Activation Functions
Activation functions are broadly divided into two types:

Linear Activation Function
Non-Linear Activation Function







Thoughts:

title: Notes on Results Metrics
text:
Results

Background


Why different result metrics
The purpose of loss function is to quantify the error between the output of an algorithm and the given target value.

Let‚Äôs say that I have 100 pieces of something and I want the algorithm to predict the number of pieces available. Here, 100 pieces are the ground truth or the target value. Now, if the algorithm predicts that there are only 90 pieces, there is a loss or error of 10 pieces.



Types of Metrics

Precision : Accuracy of positive prediction of all items classified as positive, how many were actually positive True Positive/ (True Positive + False Positive)
Recall : Sensitivity or True Positive Rate. Of all the actual positive instances, how many were correctly identified by the model True Positive/ (True Positive + False Negative)



Thoughts:

title: Statistics in AI
text: It is a statistical method that compares how the model compares against actual observed data.

title: Statistics in AI
text:
Bayes‚Äô Theorem
Bayes Theorem is a mathematical formula to determine conditional probability.
Bayes theorem relies on prior probability to generate posterior probability.

title: Statistics in AI
text:
Correlation
It is a statistical measure that describes the degree to which two variables change together. Correlation coefficient such as Pearson‚Äôs correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to 1. 1 => Perfect positive correlation. This implies that if one variable increases then the other variable also increases proportionally. -1 => Perfect negative correlation. This implies that if one variable increases then the other variable also decreases proportionally. 0 => No linear correlation between variables.
Correlation does not imply causation.

title: Chandan Kumar
text:
import pandas as pd
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt, gridspec, ticker, dates
import time
import seaborn as sns

sns.set_style("darkgrid")


data = pd.read_csv("./posts/skierg-marathon/concept2-result-79965221.csv")


fig = plt.figure(figsize=(6, 8), dpi=600)

gs = gridspec.GridSpec(3, 1, height_ratios=[2,1,1])
gs.update(hspace=0.2)

ax1 = plt.subplot(gs[0])
ax1.set_ylim(pd.to_datetime(190, unit="s"), pd.to_datetime(130, unit="s"))
ax1.plot(data["Distance (meters)"], pd.to_datetime(data["Pace (seconds)"], unit="s"), color="#2f4b7c", alpha=0.3, linewidth=0.5)
ax1.plot(data["Distance (meters)"], pd.to_datetime(data["Pace (seconds)"].rolling(33).mean(), unit="s"), color="#2f4b7c", alpha=0.6, linewidth=0.75)
ax1.plot(data["Distance (meters)"], pd.to_datetime(data["Pace (seconds)"].rolling(66).mean(), unit="s"), color="#2f4b7c", alpha=0.9, linewidth=1.25)
ax1.set_ylabel("Pace")
ax1.xaxis.set_visible(False)
ax1.yaxis.set_major_formatter(dates.DateFormatter(fmt="%M:%S"))
ax1.set_xlim(0, 42195)
plt.gca().invert_yaxis()

ax2 = plt.subplot(gs[1])
ax2.plot(data["Distance (meters)"], data["Watts"], color="#2f4b7c", alpha=0.3, linewidth=0.5)
ax2.plot(data["Distance (meters)"], data["Watts"].rolling(33).mean(), color="#2f4b7c", alpha=0.6, linewidth=0.75)
ax2.plot(data["Distance (meters)"], data["Watts"].rolling(66).mean(), color="#2f4b7c", alpha=0.9, linewidth=1.25)
ax2.set_ylabel("Watts")
ax2.set_xlim(0, 42195)
ax2.xaxis.set_visible(False)

ax3 = plt.subplot(gs[2])
ax3.plot(data["Distance (meters)"], data["Stroke Rate"], color="#2f4b7c", alpha=0.3, linewidth=0.5)
ax3.plot(data["Distance (meters)"], data["Stroke Rate"].rolling(33).mean(), color="#2f4b7c", alpha=0.6, linewidth=0.75)
ax3.plot(data["Distance (meters)"], data["Stroke Rate"].rolling(66).mean(), color="#2f4b7c", alpha=0.9, linewidth=1.25)
ax3.set_ylim(30, 55)
ax3.set_ylabel("spm")

ax3.xaxis.set_major_formatter(ticker.StrMethodFormatter("{x:,.0f}"))
ax3.set_xticks(ax3.get_xticks())
ax3.set_xticklabels(ax3.get_xticklabels(), rotation=90)
ax3.set_xlabel("metres")
ax3.set_xlim(0, 42195)

plt.show()







Figure¬†1: Stroke level data for the SkiErg marathon.






data["ddistance"] = data["Distance (meters)"].diff()
data["dtime"] = data["Time (seconds)"].diff()


g = sns.jointplot(data=data, 
                  x="dtime", 
                  y="ddistance", 
                  xlim=(0.5, 3), 
                  ylim=(2, 8), 
                  color="#2f4b7c", 
                  kind="reg", 
                  x_jitter=0.2, 
                  y_jitter=0.2, 
                  scatter_kws=dict(alpha=0.3, s=0.2))
g.plot_joint(sns.kdeplot, 
             color="#a05195", 
             zorder=0, 
             levels=16, 
             alpha=0.6, 
             fill=True)
g.set_axis_labels(ylabel="$\Delta_{d}, m$", 
                  xlabel="$\Delta_t, s$")
plt.show()







Figure¬†2: Stroke level data of stroke length (metres) versus stroke duration (seconds).

title: Corona in den USA: Mediziner warnen nun vor Injektion von Desinfektionsmittel
text:
My comment on the use of disinfectants as a treatment for COVID-19 was published in the Frankfurter Rundschau ‚Äì along with some skepticism about sunlight as the best disinfectant:

Beim Sonnenlicht als Corona-Faktor beruft sich das Wei√üe Haus auf eine Studie, die im ‚ÄúNational Biodefense Analysis and Countermeasures Center‚Äù im Bundesstaat Maryland gemacht worden sein soll. Demnach schrumpft das Virus auf einer Edelstahloberfl√§che im Sonnenlicht bei einer Temperatur von 21 bis 24 Grad Celsius und 80 Prozent Luftfeuchtigkeit innerhalb von nur zwei Minuten auf die H√§lfte seiner Gr√∂√üe - verglichen mit sechs Stunden im Dunkeln.
Die Tatsache, dass es jedoch keine weiteren Details dar√ºber gibt, wie das Experiment ausgef√ºhrt wurde, sorgt f√ºr Kopfsch√ºtteln bei Wissenschaftlern. ‚ÄúEs sieht so aus, als h√§tte jemand irgendwo ein Experiment durchgef√ºhrt‚Äù, sagte Benjamin Neuman, Vorsitzender der Biowissenschaften an der Texas A&M University-Texarkana, der Nachrichtenagentur AFP. ‚ÄúAls Wissenschaftler w√ºrde ich nat√ºrlich gerne eine aktuelle Studie und die tats√§chlichen Zahlen sehen‚Äù, sagte der Virusepidemiologe Chris von Csefalvay. Mediziner reagierten fassungslos auf die √Ñu√üerungen des Pr√§sidenten und warnten eindringlich davor, sich Desinfektionsmittel zu spritzen oder zu schlucken. Dies k√∂nne t√∂dliche Folgen haben.

Read the whole thing here.
And on that note, the Manila Times also quoted me on the same topic.

Assistant Professor, Computer Science
Alfred University, New York
I am an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Alfred University and a researcher in Computer Vision and Deep Learning, specializing in unsupervised learning, real-time
vision systems, and multimodal foundation models. I completed my Ph.D.¬†at Iowa State
University, where my research focused on scalable computer vision methods for object
discovery, semantic segmentation, and building footprint reconstruction.
I worked at the intersection of theory and practice through research collaborations with
Oak Ridge National Laboratory, with publications in top-tier venues such as ICLR and
CVPR and support from NSF-funded projects. My work emphasizes developing robust,
real-world AI systems, and I actively contribute to the research community as a reviewer
for leading conferences including ECCV, ICML, and NeurIPS.






üì¢ News Highlights



Two new Research Publications. Nov, 2025


Gave a talk at AU Energy. Oct, 2025


Started working as Assistant Professor at Alfred University. Aug,2025

title: Teaching
text: I am an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Alfred University and have taught as a Mentor/Teaching Assistant at Iowa State University. My teaching focuses on connecting theory with practical applications through hands-on, project-driven learning, with emphasis on machine learning, AI, scientific computing, and web technologies.

title: Teaching
section: Courses I Teach at Alfred University

title: Teaching
section: Courses I Served as TA / Mentor at Iowa State University

title: Teaching
Teaching
text:
Teaching Experience



CSCI156 ‚Äì Computer Science I
Fall 2025 ¬∑ Spring 2026


    This course introduces fundamental programming concepts using 
    Python,including conditional statements, loops, recursion, 
    procedural programming,variable scope, doc-strings, unit testing, 
    dictionaries, simulations, modules,packages, and object-oriented 
    programming.
</div>




CSCI400 ‚Äì AI for Computer Vision
Fall 2025 ¬∑ Spring 2026


  A project-based course covering modern computer vision techniques using deep learning.
  Topics include CNNs, Transformers, Vision Transformers, and real-world applications.
  Students gain hands-on experience with industry-relevant AI workflows.
</div>




CS 311 ‚Äì Algorithms


  Supported students in algorithm design and analysis, including dynamic programming,
  greedy algorithms, and computational complexity.
</div>



CSCI156 Computer Science I Fall 2025, Spring 2026
This course is an introduction to the fundamental concepts of computer programming using Python. Topics include conditional statements, loops, recursion, procedural programming, scope of variables, doc-strings, unit-testing, dictionaries, simulation, creating and using modules and packages, and object-oriented programming.
CSCI400 AI for Computer Vision Fall 2025, Spring 2026
Recently, the advancements in Deep Learning have propelled Computer Vision forward.This project-based course will explore the advances in Computer Vision and Deep Learning and aims at providing students with hands-on experience with AI, particularly in Computer Vision. Topics include Convolutional Neural Networks(CNNs), Transformers, Vision Transformers etc. and their applications to Computer Vision.The course aims at making the students industry ready with practical experience with real- world applications and advance in the field of AI.

Iowa State University
COMS 1130 ‚Äì Spreadsheets and Databases Fall 2024
Using Microsoft Excel spreadsheets and Microsoft Access databases to input, store, process, manipulate, query, and analyze data for business and industrial applications. Graduation Restriction: Credit in COMS 1130 may not be applied toward graduation in the SE and CPRE majors.
COMS 1060 - Introduction to Web Programming Spring 2017,Fall 2017, Spring 2018
Introduction to web programming basics. Fundamentals of developing web pages using a comprehensive web development life cycle. Learn to design and code practical real-world homepage programs and earn adequate experience with current web design techniques such as HTML5 and cascading style sheets. Students also learn additional programming languages including JavaScript, jQuery, PHP, SQL, and MySQL. Strategies for accessibility, usability and search engine optimization. No prior computer programming experience necessary.
AI 2010 - Introduction to Applied AI Fall 2024
Broad introduction to AI, focusing on its applications and impact across different fields and industries. Provides an overview of AI concepts, terminology, and real-world examples, allowing students to understand how AI is transforming various domains. Basic introduction of societal implications, ethical considerations, and potential challenges associated with AI. Opportunities to collaborate and use AI to address real-world challenges.

AI 2010 - Introduction to Applied AI Fall 2024
Broad introduction to AI, focusing on its applications and impact across different fields and industries. Provides an overview of AI concepts, terminology, and real-world examples, allowing students to understand how AI is transforming various domains. Basic introduction of societal implications, ethical considerations, and potential challenges associated with AI. Opportunities to collaborate and use AI to address real-world challenges.

title: Teaching
text:
Current Teaching (Assistant Professor)



CSCI156 ‚Äì Computer Science I
Fall 2025 , Spring 2026


      This course is an introduction to the fundamental concepts of computer  
      programming using Python.Topics include conditional statements, loops,  
      recursion, procedural programming, scope of  variables, doc-strings,  
      unit-testing, dictionaries, simulation, creating and using modules   
      and packages,and object-oriented programming.



CSCI400 ‚Äì AI for Computer Vision
Fall 2025 , Spring 2026


  The advancements in Deep Learning have propelled Computer Vision forward.  
  This project-based course explores advances in Computer Vision and Deep Learning,  
  providing students hands-on experience with AI, particularly in Computer Vision.  
  Topics include Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Transformers, Vision  
  Transformers, and their applications. The course aims to make students  
  industry-ready with practical experience in real-world AI applications.



Iowa State University

Mentoring / Teaching Assistant



AI 2010 ‚Äì Introduction to Applied AI
Fall 2024


  Broad introduction to AI, focusing on applications and impact across  
  different fields and industries. Provides an overview of AI concepts,  
  terminology, and real-world examples, allowing students to understand  
  how AI is transforming various domains. Includes societal implications,  
  ethical considerations, and potential challenges associated with AI.



COMS 1130 ‚Äì Spreadsheets and Databases
Fall 2024


  Using Microsoft Excel spreadsheets and Microsoft Access databases to  
  input,store, process, manipulate, query, and analyze data for business   
  and industrial applications. 



COMS 1060 ‚Äì Introduction to Web Programming
Spring 2017 , Fall 2017 , Spring 2018


  Introduction to web programming basics. Fundamentals of developing web   
  pages using a comprehensive web development life cycle. Learn to design  
  and code practical real-world homepage programs and gain experience with  
  current web design techniques such as HTML5 and CSS. Students also learn  
  additional programming languages including JavaScript, jQuery, PHP, SQL,  
  and MySQL. Covers accessibility, usability, and search engine optimization.

title: Curriculum Vitae
text:
Professional Summary
Assistant Professor of Computer Science with a Ph.D.¬†specializing in Computer Vision and Deep Learning. Experienced researcher with expertise in unsupervised learning, multimodal foundation models, and edge computing, with research appointments at Oak Ridge National Laboratory and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory. Published author with 10+ peer-reviewed papers in top-tier venues and recipient of $180K+ NSF funding. Strong ability to bridge academic research with real-world applications.
